The crawler generally keeps writing to the same log files it's already 
opened, so (as with usual Linux/Unix filesystem beahvior), renaming or 
even deleting those files doesn't change the target of the crawler's 
output.

If you start using checkpointing (either manually or via the automatic 
interval), the crawler will rotate its own logs each checkpoint (moving 
the existing log to a file with a timestamp suffix).

I think you could also trigger this on demand by calling the 
CrawlerLoggerModule.rotateLogFiles() public methods, either from the 
ScriptingConsole or your own custom module, but I haven't tested that to 
ensure it works as might be expected.

- Gordon @ IA

On 12/9/10 3:57 AM, Mahmoud Mubarak wrote:
>
> Is there a property to rotate Heritrix logs? I use

> with /etc/logrotate.d/heritrix_crawl:
>
> /usr/local/heritrix/jobs/my-job/logs/*.log {
> rotate 100
> size=1000M
> compress
> create 644 webcrawl webcrawl
> }
>
> but it didn't work well. Heritrix didn't write in the new crawl.log file
> after compressing the first 1G. I didn't know why, did you?
>
> Anyway, I want to rotate the logs from heritrix not by logrotate as it
> will be very compatible.
>
> Thanks in advance.
